stem: The nurse is evaluating two clients on the medical-surgical unit. Based on the clinical data in the EHR, match each assessment finding to the appropriate fluid volume state.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A (Ms. Green, 78 years old): Admitted with HFrEF exacerbation. Reports increasing dyspnea and 'tight' shoes. Nurse notes a cough productive of frothy pink sputum. 
Patient B (Mr. White, 82 years old): Admitted with viral gastroenteritis; reports 10+ episodes of vomiting and diarrhea in the last 24 hours. Client appears lethargic and reports feeling 'extremely dizzy' when sitting up.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Ms. Green (A): Bilateral 3+ pitting edema to the mid-calf. Fine crackles noted in lower lung lobes. S3 gallop present on auscultation. 
Mr. White (B): Mucous membranes parched. Skin over sternum remains tented for 4 seconds after pinch. Capillary refill > 4 seconds. Peripheral pulses are weak and thready.

rows.text: Audible S3 gallop and crackles in lung bases
Postural hypotension and thready peripheral pulses
Increased hematocrit and urine specific gravity
Visible jugular venous distension (JVD) at 45 degrees

rationale.correct: Fluid volume excess (FVE) involves hemodilution (low hematocrit), distended veins, and fluid back-up into the lungs (S3/crackles). Fluid volume deficit (FVD) involves hemoconcentration (high hematocrit/BUN), thready pulses, and high urine specific gravity as the body tries to conserve water. The EHR data for Patient A (Green) aligns with FVE cues, while Patient B (White) shows classic FVD cues due to diarrhea and vomiting.
clinicalPearls: Weight change is the MOST accurate indicator of fluid status. (1 kg = 1 L of fluid).
For FVE, listen for the 'lub-dub-TA' (S3), which indicates fluid hitting a non-compliant ventricle.
In FVD, the BUN often rises out of proportion to the creatinine (Ratio > 20:1).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that crackles automatically mean pneumonia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the JVD and weight. If both are elevated, the crackles are more likely pulmonary edema (FVE).

mnemonic.title: FVE vs FVD
mnemonic.expansion: FVE: Wet, Weighty, Wide veins (JVD). FVD: Dry, Dizzy, Depleted (Labs High).
